origination.persname: de Vienne, Field Marshall Comte. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that the enclosed letter to his son, the Marquis de Vienne, may be forwarded to America; his son complains that, though he has received the rank of colonel, his services, in other respects, have not been suitably recognized; begs Franklin to recommend him in his letters to Congress and to General Washington.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to deliver the memoir of Messieurs Risteau, of Bordeaux; hopes their reasons will determine Captain McNeill to finish an affair, which has lasted too long.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has invented a new variety of beer, which has remarkable advantages; is willing to sell his secret.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a copy of Amsterdam's Resolutions, à propos of increasing the army in Holland (22 p.); intrigues of the English party aim to increase the army of Holland at the expense of her navy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His hatred of oppression and tyranny; his ardent desire to serve under the standard of liberty.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if his father, Captain Thomas Turner, is in the American service.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Le Maire de Gimel, Jacques. Nantes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reiterates his request for an answer to the Governor of Virginia's letter, also for a recommendation in favor of M. Doumolon; offers to carry any despatches Franklin cares to intrust to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning two bills of exchange.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Chevalier de Raimondis, late Captain of the "Cæsar," one of Comte d'Estaing's squadron, had the misfortune to lose his arm in an engagement off the coast; his subsequent stay in Boston, and the presentation to him by the Council of Massachusetts of a fine sword; hopes he will be generously rewarded for his sufferings and heroic behavior. The enemy likely to evacuate New York and Rhode Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a general order, forbidding British subjects to settle in French sea-ports; begs that he and Mr. Thompson's two sons may be permitted to reside unmolested at Nantes, being convinced that his commercial interest will be of general advantage to France and America; his and Mr. Thompson's strong sentiments in favor of the country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from Dr. Williams, of London, and begging Franklin's compliance with his request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of Count d'Estaing's fleet; report prevails that Admiral Byron's fleet left New York, November 2d with 5,000 troops on board. The Boston, Providence and Ranger arrived at Boston with many prizes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informs him that his son, who is just out of the University and whose talent is scarcely known, took passage for France with Mr. John Adams, under whose care he placed him, with a view to accomplish him for business either as a merchant or in any other way, that he might be most useful in the future to his country. Hopes he may regard him as one of his friends and that he will, from time to time, receive such advice and instructions from his friends as will stimulate him to virtue, honor and knowledge.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Another blow to the English party in the shape of the enclosed memoir (1 p.) from the French Ambassador, asking an explanation of Holland's future conduct and demanding the most perfect neutrality.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reasons for holding back his last letter to Franklin. The only important struggle is with the currency; the aid of skilful financiers and monied men needed to bring about any considerable appreciation.
(In triplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Conformable to the enclosed Resolution of Congress, has drawn upon them for a certain sum. Report of a Congress to be held between the Ministers from the Courts of Versailles and St. Petersburg, to arrange a reconciliation between the Emperor and the King of Prussia; also reported that Great Britain has prevailed on Russia to take advantage of this opportunity to negotiate an accommodation between France and Great Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the enclosed memorial from the prisoners on the "Patience"; their situation most deplorable and their complaints just; declares that Rivu, who has charge of them, is a scoundrel and begs them to send their answer through the Reverend Father John, as otherwise it will never reach the prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The arrival of the schooner "Dauphin," from Boston; brings news of the loss to England of the "Somerset" man-of-war, and the unfortunate capture of the frigate " Raleigh," after an obstinate engagement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the exchange of prisoners; announcing the acceptance, by the Admiralty, of the last terms submitted by Franklin.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, I, 211.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Urging the necessity of having an agent in London, and recommending Captain Robinson for the position. Dietary for prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing some bills of exchange which he begs Franklin to lay out for him and his son-in law, Major Samuel Ward; the latter's desire to receive consignments of cargoes from merchants in France. Recommending to Franklin's kindness Mr. William Vernon, Jr., now in France, for the purpose of studying the language. Family news.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote three weeks ago concerning a passport to enable him to return to Charleston; begs him not to forget his request.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to know if Franklin has received a letter of advice concerning the bill of exchange mentioned in his last letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification of bills of exchange furnished to the States of Pennsylvania New Jersey.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses copies of their letters written to Arthur Lee, with his reply; their object in sending them is not to complain of their colleague, but to guard against future misrepresentation.
(Copies in French of a rather acrid correspondence between Messiura D'Acosta and Mr. Arthur Lee concerning the packing of certain articles bound for Virgina.)
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a mistake by which Mr. Deane's goods were shipped to America by Mr. Schweighauser.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Colonel Driks, from Holland; he has served with reputation and honor in the defense of America and has leave of absence to settle his affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to obtain from M. de Sartine, a special dispensation that he may be exempted from service on the King's ships; desires this in order to accept command of a merchant ship bound for Charleston.
A. E. by Franklin. As a stranger in France, begs to be excused from troubling the Ministers with solicitation for persons unknown to him, and in affairs of which he is ignorant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending M. de Weiss Daillens.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her husband forced by illness to give up his service to the Elector Palatine; their small resources; impossible to take her huband to Aix; applies to franklin for assistance; places her hopes in the fact that her husband and Franklin are both Masons, though belonging to different lodges.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his arrival in the brig, "Morris," and asking for instruction as to his future movements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Submits proposal to raise a body of 240 volunteers to serve in the United States in the war of independence.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: A. Sube, Laporte, and others. Marseilles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recounting a fête, recently celebrated by the Société de Parnasse in honor of their good friends and allies, the insurgents; encloses a printed paper which will give him the proceedings in detail; Franklin's portrait, crowned with laurel, had the place of honor; the influence it exerted on the company.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has reason to believe that a plan of reconciliation between France and Great Britain will be agitated at the Congress mentioned in his last letter; suggests the advisability of having an agent there to counteract the schemes of Great Britain; has sounded a gentleman on the subject, at present in the service of the King of Prussia; and transcribes his answer; asks their opinion of his propositions; advises his going to the Congress as an authorized individual.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conway, Françoise-Antoinette-Jeanne Langlois du Bouchet, comtesse de. Auxerre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires news of her husband, of Franklin's health, and of the war in America; intends to call on him during the winter.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Schweighauser, John D, et al. Merchants at Nantes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hope, through the Commissioner's efforts, to secure a convoy for their vessels for the entire voyage across the Atlantic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extract from Mr. A. Lee's letter, heaping reproaches on Holland for her reluctance to aid the United States and threatening them with exclusion from future benefits; embarrassed how to tell him that he is ignorant of the state of the Republic and says what is neither just nor reasonable; explains the situation to Franklin; ask him to keep this letter secret.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains of receiving no answer to his last letters; there is still time for him to rejoin his regiment, if his necessary expenses are defrayed at once; anguish of mind he suffers in such a humiliating situation, which has been brought about by the chance of war.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Beaulieu, Charles Gilloton (?), chevalier de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prophesies a magnificent future for America, and a deathless fame for Franklin; desires to serve this astonishing people.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their vessel has been set free and her freight paid; desires Franklin's interest as regards the merchandise with which she was loaded.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His promise to send Mr. Benjamin Vaughan the "Tableau Economique", published by M. Dupont. Desires Franklin to procure an extension of leave for his brother, Duportail, who left two years before to serve in the American army, and also for the three engineers he took with him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to have the enclosed letter conveyed safely to Mr. Coxe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to come to them on the following day; number of Franklin's friends who will be present and several pretty women.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Exchange of prisoners will be hurried forward now without delay; begs Franklin to name the port and the agent, and he will immediately receive a hundred prisoners, to begin with; desires to know if Morlaix will suit for further exchanges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of the pleasant hours they once spent together; Mrs. Baldwin's pride in a wax bust of Franklin, the present of their friend Moore, as well as his liturgy, which is her constant Sunday entertainment. The loss of Dominica has meant a heavy financial loss to them; his only son is now at Portsmouth, on route for Dominica to take charge of the estate there; begs Franklin to recommend him to the Marquis de Bouillé. Has told his son of Franklin's cabin lamp.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires the position of Consul at Calais.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks questions, bearing on the right of a people to throw off their Sovereign's yoke, and desires concise, clear and reasonable answers to them.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. "Imp[ertinen]t demand".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to establish himself in America and begs Franklin to grant him his protection and a passport.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just escaped from captivity in England. Sends a memoir in which he gives an account of his services to the United States and in particular to the state of Maryland, having been in command of the "Conqueror," the "Dolphin" and other war vessels. Fought several engagements with the English and capture some of their vessels. Finally fell into the hands of English privateers while in command of a merchant vessel and was brought to England.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to serve in the American army; begs Franklin to procure him the rank of officer in the grenadiers; offers to bring with him four young men, relatives of his.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a position in the American army for a captain in his regiment.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Capt. Pickerin, Thomas. Brest. (On board the Hampden.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His arrival at Brest with two prizes; uncertain as to whether the cargo of the second one is Spanish or English property; the Court of Admiralty have taken the vessel into their immediate care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking their intervention for the release of an American prisoner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Containing an account of a prize-ship from Bristol, loaded with cod-fish, which was captured by John Leach, of the Franklin, and afterwards wrecked on the French coast near Bayonne; disposition made of the cargo and ship's furnishings saved from the wreck.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transmitting the enclosed memorials and proposals from a worthy friend of his, Mr. J----- N-----, illy rewarded in England for his long services there, and at present Chamberlain to the Elector at Heidelberg. Fears Franklin's determined silence to all his letters is due to slanders circulated by his enemies to his discredit. Concerning the union of the thirteen Confederate States with the thirteen Cantons; proposes himself for the position of American agent in Switzerland. Offers his collection of books, minerals, fossils, etc., for sale. Urges the excellence of Swiss linen to supply the deficiency in America of the Scotch and Irish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Confides in the friendship shown by Franklin to Mme. de Flavigny and himself; has been ill four years, and is at present in sore need of money, which he begs Franklin to advance him; promises to repay him with twelve hundred bottles of excellent wine.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his right to vessels recaptured as prizes.
(Copy in French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his right to a recaptured prize, the "La Constance."

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to add the enclosed letters to the first despatches sent to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the investment of American promissory notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His request for a passport to enable him to return to Charleston, where he lost twelve houses in the late fire; begs for the loan of four Louis d'or.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The death of her brave husband, leaves her with no means of educate her son; applies to Franklin to place the boy in some school, either of artillery or engineering; the injustice of depriving her of a pension.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His son at his Seigniory of Vaudreuil near Quebec; in case of any intended movement against Canada, begs Franklin to mention his son's family to Congress, as well as the affair of his two seigniories situated at the head of Lake Champlain. England's present disposition to withdraw from the struggle.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Not receiving any answer to his last letter has drawn upon them in favour of Mr. Schweighauser for 1,000 livres.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Samuel Bradford, who goes to France to perfect himself in the language.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses the acts previously spoken of for Franklin's name and seal. Concerning the Loan Office Bills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes that the time which has elapsed since his departure from Paris has not entirely effaced Franklin's remembrance of one who has always been sincerely attached to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has drawn upon them for one thousand livres and it will have a very bad appearance in the eyes of the world, if his draft is refused; their protracted silence made it too late for him to apply for relief elsewhere.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bearer will wait for the manuscript in question, but if the matter is not ended, begs that the packet may be returned at his earliest convenience.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certifying to having examined, with Dr. Franklin, the trunk containing the public and private papers of the late Thomas Morris Esq., and to having found the seals and strings upon the said trunk entire.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Had the pleasure of sitting between Franklin and the poet Rocher at dinner, the day they celebrated the Apotheosis of Voltaire. Is deputed by the Chamber of Commerce, at Languedoc, to ascertain the products of the United States; desires an audience for this purpose.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has endeavored to procure occuption for the young American recommended by Franklin, but his absolute ignorance of French is an insurmountable obstacle; should he acquire some slight knowledge of the language will do his best to obtain employment for him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to serve in the American army; is lieutenant in the Royal Grenadiers, and has seen twenty-two years of service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The arrival, at Morlaix, of the ship "Morris," Captain Benjamin Gunnisson, loaded with tobacco; desires Franklin's orders concerning her treatment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The remembrance of his late imprisonment makes him desirous of doing something for those he left behind. Urges the desirability of having an agent in London, who can assist the prisoners, after their escape, to reach France; the Rev. Mr. Denward recommends Captain Moses Robertson as the most suitable person; if nothing is done for the prisoners, they will go on board King's ships-of-war and fight against their brethren.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Continues his demand for support according to his rank in the United States army; if Mr. Livingston's ship sails without him, he will be obliged to make the whole affair public; begs that his draft may be honored at once.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petitions them to use their influence, in his behalf, with M. de Sartine, so that he may obtain from among the foreigners captured in English ships, sailors to take the place of deserters and enable him to return to Baltimore with his vessel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning Thomas Pickerin's prize vessel, "La Constance."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter for his brother, Duportail. Request Franklin to have his brother's and his fellow-engineer's furlough renewed by the French Ministry to enable them to serve in the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the recapture of La Constance, of Bordeaux, by Captain Pickerin; begs Franklin to take the matter into consideration, and obtain a prompt withdrawal of the arrest put upon this vessel and her cargo.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: By order of Congress, a general tribute of prayer and thanksgiving is offered up that day throughout the land. Thinks England must be convinced, by this time, that the Western Hemisphere is not to be conquered like slaves of the East. Two public addresses in the newspaper, one by General Lee, in which General W[ashingto]n's character is indirectly attacked; the other, by Silas Deane containing certain revelations of an alarming nature. The high breeding and politeness of Court d'Estaing and the French officers, contrasts strikingly with English naval civility. Introducing Mr. Samuel Bradford to Franklin's friendly notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a young relative who embarked for America two years before, without friends or letters; his success and speedy promotion; begs Franklin to mention him favorably in his letters to Congress. Recommends his wines to Franklin's notice.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for redress for the refusal of the French authorities at Brest to allow him to come into the harbor for repairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Through no fault of his own, has lost everything, even his position, and is likely soon to die of hunger; compares himself to Virgil, with this difference, that he had all his goods restored by the Emperor; trusts to the King and to Franklin for some such happy outcome to his misery,
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for his kind reception at Passy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "The young Lion and the Mastiff." Allegorical fable by Franklin put in verse.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "The Gold-finch and the Eagle." An allegorical fable containing allusions to Franklin and his services to America. Poem.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "The eagle and the Cat." An allegorical fable of Franklin's put in verse. Poem.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a memoir by M. de I'Oiseau, which he begs Franklin to present to the ministers; question of his and his brother's estate in Grenada.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Seven English prisoners forcibly put on board their ship in September, 1777, by Captain Etienne of the corsair "La Bellone"; applies for the promised indemnity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Scheme for establishing a base for hostile operations at Monaco against English vessels.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A few lines from Mr. [Silas] Deane dated, Philadelphia, 6th September, 1778, and referring to packets which he had just sealed. Supposes they must have come under cover to Dr. Franklin; begs he will, in that case, send them by bearer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepts invitation to dine with him next Thursday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends him the volume of Dr. Cullen's lectures containing his sentiments on the gout; will send the other volumes if they are desired.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Dr. Franklin to forward an enclosed letter to Mr.Carmichael.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter to be forwarded to destination.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks to be appointed Consul for the United States at Cette.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin to interest himself in the memorial enclosed.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter to be forwarded to philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: If Dr. Franklin has written the letters for Marshal de Castries will he please deliver them to bearer. Incloses a small bill which the Baron de Montesquieu gave him in payment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his capture by the English when fifteen miles from Charlestown, of his cruel treatment at St. Augustine, and his loss of all money, valuables and even linen; other French officers in irons in the same prison; begs Franklin to send him a certificate of service, which will help greatly in procuring him a wished-for advancement.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Dr. Franklin to give bearer letters for him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cannot entertain him at tea that evening. Tells him to give that evening to her amiable rival, Mme. Helvétius. Will dine at his house on Sunday as usual.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to take tea with her and her family in the afternoon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter in anonymous form giving the views of a certain lady on love as opposed to those of a certain gentleman {Franklin). She asserts that she is a follower of Plato, while he is an Epicurean and a disciple of Anacreon. Platonic love is a convenient safeguard for the fair sex (beau sexe). Exculpates herself from the accusation of showing or giving copies to others of the gentleman's letters to her without his consent. Attributes his displeasure and bad humor to her refusal to accept his proposals of love.
(In French.)
In duplicate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reproaches Franklin for having forsaken her the day before. She was searching for the books he wanted and now sends them to him. M. du Bospin's library is at his disposal. Loves Franklin tenderly but not furiously or too much, as Franklin says he loves her.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Protests against Franklin's reason for not coming to her house oftener that he feared to be importunate or become a burden. Always welcomed him and received him cordially.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Seven English prisoners forcibly put on board his ship in September, 1777, by Captain Etienne of the corsair "La Bellone"; applies for the promised indemnity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His book on the grinding of corn presented to Franklin by the Prior of Cardone; Franklin's promise to come and see his mill; begs him to bring a friend and dine with them the following day.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies for the appointment of United States Consul at Dieppe.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Why his "History of England" is slow in appearing; refuses to accept the present or charity.
(In French.)
(In Complete.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a hotel at Versailles where Franklin put up when going to Court.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his disbursements to escaped American prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers a cargo of salt beef at a certain price.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to act as Consul at the seaports in Provence and Languedoc.
(In French. In duplicate.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conway, Françoise-Antoinette-Jeanne Langlois du Bouchet, comtesse de. Auxerre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is prepared to set out for America, if Franklin thinks it advisable. Will be happy to live under the laws of "good man Richard."

origination.persname: Conway, Françoise-Antoinette-Jeanne Langlois du Bouchet, comtesse de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests Franklin to send an enclosed letter to her husband who, to her surprise, has not received her previous letters. Asks for news about him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposed agreement for furnishing 1,000 bayonet rifles.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies for appointment as Consul for the United States at Havre.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a young German who desires employment in the service of Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to forward the inclosed letter to his brother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to make his acquaintance. Is the author of a memoir presented to Dr. Franklin by M. Montaudouin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applying for the Consulship of the United States, at Dunkerque.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Application for appointment as Consul for the United States at Boulogne.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposal to purchase and convey goods to America. He has recommended a person to be American Consul in Normandy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applying for the post of Consul for the United States at Bayonne and St. Jean-de-Luz.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Secret code for corresponding with Dr. Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests interview; anxious to know what has happened since Count d'Estaing left Sandy Hook.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Worked on board the ship "Commerce," commanded by Captain Robert Mercer; falsely accused of stealing some of the cargo; begs Franklin to see justice done him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to recommend M. Comyn for the position of American Consul at Marseilles; enclosing a copy of his letter on this subject to the Count Pulaski, a Polish officer in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Are merchants and make application for the office of Consul of the United States at Calais and Dieppe, respectively.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applying for the post of Consul at Calais.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: While passing through Turin, the Baron de Choiseul, the French Ambassador, entrusted him with the enclosed for Franklin; desires to pay his respects at the earliest favorable moment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deputed by his colleague, M. Anquetil Duperron, to present Franklin with his book, "Legislation Orientale."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin to forward a letter to a French officer in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects him on Saturday, will wait for him in the Tuilleries.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminds Franklin he is to take tea with her on Wednesday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Suggesting to Franklin a way of receiving his two Gazettes regularly from London, by having them addressed to " Monsieur Genet, à Versailles."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if it would be possible for a Jew to be named consul for the United States at Marseilles.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging his assistance to procure him a position as tutor, or work as a translator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies for the appointment of Consul for the United States in Normandy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies for the appointment of Consul for the United States at Cette. Is recommended by M. Le Veillard.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging the loan, for a few days, of the latest Paris Journal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certificate authorizing him to brew and sell the new kind of beer which he has discovered.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks whether the "Ranger" should depart before her prizes are realized; whether the advances must be deducted; and whether it is not inexpedient for a ship that sails slow and is of trifling force to pursue a track where there is almost a certainty of meeting with the enemy's fast-sailing ships of superior force.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Insubordination on the "Ranger"; conduct of Lieutenant Simpson which led up to his imprisonment.
(Incomplete.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The prisoners taken by the "Ranger."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Messrs. Frankinn for the news they sent him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a navigator and ship captain; offers his services to the United States Congress of fit out a vessel to wage war on English shipping.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Embarrasing situation in which his voyage to America has placed him; thinks Franklin will see the justice of making him some amends; desires permission to obtain a certain sum from Franklin's bankers every week, for his necessary expenses while in Paris.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin that he sailed for America to serve in the capacity of Colonel, that he defrayed all his own expenses, and that he had the misfortune to be captured and imprisoned by the English; recalls Franklin's application to Congress to grant him the title of Colonel as a recompense for all his losses; begs to be informed of their reply; honors bestowed on him by the King of France.
(In French.)

origination.persname: La Blancherie, Claude-Mammès de Pahin Champlain de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him a second invitation to their Assembly [Rendez-vous de la République des Letters et des. Arts], and urging him to come.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of the new town, sent to him by one of the exiles from Geneva.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter which he has written to Captain Jones an account of his conversation with M. de Sartine.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No alteration taken place as yet with respect to the frigate "Bordeaux." Girard's advice concerning M. Beaumarchais's account.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposed receipt for certain papers taken from the trunk of Thomas Morris, deceased.
A. E. by Dr. Franklin that he had declined to sign it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks Franklin's opinion of the dedicatory preface to the Thirteen United States of the "Tableau de l'Histoire de Hollande." Inquires also if Franklin wishes to be appointed a member of the Commission to be named by the Academy to report on a project for keeping in communication with all the learned men of Europe.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if Franklin has received any news about Count d'Estaing.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends report on the project of M. de la Blancherie. Asks leave to bring Abbé Le Noble to dinner. Requests Dr. Franklin to send him Ingen Housz's observations on priestley's discovery relatives to coal
(carbon).
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The report on the project of M. de la Blancherie will be submitted to the Academy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Commissioners appointed by the Academy will dine at his house, Hopes Franklin will not fail to attend the dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking if Franklin has not the reminder of Count de Lacepède's manuscript on electricity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received a note from the museum of M. Court de Gebelin in which they ask him to try and induce Franklin to come there to-day.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Le Roy, Mme Jean Baptiste. "La petite femme de poche."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: She sees that Franklin has forgotten her. New friends have made him forget the best and truest friends of the first hour. She was his first adopted daughter and loved him more than all the others he adopted since.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a furniture maker and machinist; offers his services to the American Commissioners.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the capture of certain American vessels.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His advantures and misfortunes while in the service of the United States. Was formerly a licutenant in the Guadeloupe Legion, came to Cambridge, Mass., Where he offered his services to the American Commander. Was wounded and taken prisoner in the first engagement with the English. Imprisoned for a long time in Boston and afterwards in England.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking help for herself and her brother who are in want.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has newspapers and journals of Congress for Franklin, received from Mr. Lovell. Message to Mr. Adams.
[First part missing.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting passage and a passport for M. de Fayet, a young officer who wishes to go to American. Has two brother officers in the army, one under M. de La Fayette.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Malherbe, Dom. Abbaye de St. Germain

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending to Franklin a young surgeon of great talent.
(In french.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to see the Procession of the Cordon Bleu at Versailles the following morning; this will not interfere with their presence at the tea-party in the afternoon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending for his little ode, "The Muse of America," which he presented to Franklin some time ago; an American friend anxious to see this trifle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering his services as Secretary to the American Commissioners; has refused "The British bread of bribery"; desires above all things a connection with cause of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his intention to give the weighty commission entrusted to him to the House of Messrs. Ambrosius Pool and Co. who are from Switzerland and may be considered totally out of all connection with the E[nglish] nation; has not the least doubt that they will give complete satisfaction in every sense. Report that the Dutch merchantmen going to their colonies will get a convoy of Dutch men-of-war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepts Franklin's proposal. Requests him to advise his grandson, Mr. Lee and Mr. Adams to that effect.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for position of American Consul-General, at Naples for M. Meuricoffre.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: lnviting Dr. Franklin and his grandson to dine with him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Are merchants of Dunkirk; give an account of services rendered by them to the United States and its subjects and ask that they be given charge of American business interests at Dunkirk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commodore Jones gone to the Texel; probability of Captain Cunningham's joining him there; thinks two of America's greatest heroes ought not to endanger their lives in the same vessel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report from London of the "Randolph" and "Columbus" being sunk by the "Yarmouth," man-of-war, and of the "Alfred" being taken by the "Ariadnc" and "Ceres."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the prizes taken by his corsair "The Hamden".
(In French.)

did.physdesc: L.S. James Falls, Gunner, et al. 3p.

origination.persname: The Peyty Officers on board the Ranger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing dissatisfaction with Captain [John Paul] Jones and requesting to be permitted to return to the United States.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Several Officers on board the Ranger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Protesting against the treatment and imprisonment of Lieutenant Simpson and testifying to his good character.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A poor poet; craves assistance to enable him to finish an epic poem against the English and to print his other works; desires to finish his days in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Addressing his poem "The Ameriquiade" to Franklin, Deane and Lee. Hope they will do something to alleviate his distress.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: de Basmarin et Raimbaux, Recules. Bordeaux

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reciting their services to the United States during the war, as merchants and shippers. Wish to obtain from the King an armed frigate to convoy their vessels to North America. Hope the Deputies from Congress will help them in their purpose.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends him Dr. Forster's observations made during a voyage around the world. States two objections to Dr. Franklin's explanation of the wood split in sundry pieces by lightning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the sale of the prize made by the "Hampden"; action taken by the Admiralty in the affair; need of Franklin's powerful protection.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Impossible for him to break his engagement, as there is an important matter connected with the dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returns copy of Resolution of Congress given him by Franklin, in mistake. Asks for copy of Resolution with reference to reports of a settlement with England. If Mr. Adams will send him his letter for Marquis de Castries he will immediately hand it to the latter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Had hoped to receive the collection of little pieces which Franklin had promised to send him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a pass from Marseilles to Naples.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advantages of going straight to New York; desires a few lines to General Washington which will enable him to pass through the lines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Late master of the ship "Lord Chatham," of Dublin, a prisoner at Brest; petitions to be released with his son-in-law and allowed to return to Dublin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Application to be appointed Consul, for the United States, at Rouen. Endorsed by Mme. de Forbach, the Dowager Duchess Des Deux-Pont, and Chevalier de Keralio.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin's influence with M. Necker to procure for him a certain situation. Owes his reputation as a poet to his verses on the insurgents.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a surgeon of the Salpétrière Hospital at Paris; offers his services to the United States.
(In French. In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His approaching departure on a cruise; personal civilities received from the French authorities cannot atone for the insult offered the States in his person as their officer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to act as correspondent or agent for the United States at Brest.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: So soon as the opportunity of conversing, with a certain man is over, will meet him publicly and tell him how much he reveres him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring an hour's conversation with Franklin concerning his brother and himself; would like to have the meeting at a neutral place, until he has gone through the ceremony of seeing Lord Stormont; Franklin aware of his reasons for sending in his name to Lord Stormont.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if he has received his despatches and if he has any news about Count d'Estaing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know at what time Franklin comes to Paris, so as to confer with him on American affairs.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mail Packet taken by an American privateer and carried into Dunkirk. Believes the news of General Lincoln's success to be authentic. Thanking him for the perusal of the inclosed foolish paper; presumably written by a Junto of American Tories, tools of Lord George Germain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for a reply to his letter of December 26th, 1777.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a bond debt due him from his brother in Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes a plan to prevent corruption and venality in judges and others who administer justice. How to expedite law-suits and avoid unnecessary expense. Judges should be elected by the people and receive a fixed salary. System adopted in Switzerland.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Song For A Brillo Party)
"The horse and his master." Song composed for and sung at the entertainment given to Franklin and his friends by M. Brillon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "To the Americans." On their struggle against England.
(In French)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reflections on the war between England and the American Colonists and stanzas to the latter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The sister of Captain Fray [De Frey?] serving in the American army, who is in distressed circumstances in France, petitions Franklin to help her by procuring promotion for her husband in the French army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The proposition of the English Ministry for peace with the United Colonies, and the advantages of an alliance with the Houses of Bourbon and of Brandenburg against the disadvantages of a treaty with England.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A proposition for peace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposal to furnish supplies and munitions of war to the United States on certain conditions.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List and particulars of cannon which could be purchased at Ferrol, Spain.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending de Wiebel.
(In Russian.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: “Captain Ayres very ill; fears he will not be able to proceed to sea; the vessel will be ready to sail by Saturday.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: “Desires their instructions in case Captain Ayers’s health does not permit him to proceed to sea. Concerning a plan he had the honor to lay before them, the results of which would tend toward the restoration to confidence of the currency of America.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: “Applies again for assistance, and gives the most pitiable account of her destitute and miserable condition.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: “News just received from Virginia; the enemy’s ships still in the Delaware; Count d’Estaing’s fleet daily expected; General Washington’s army consists of 18,000 men; the people in high spirits and the money increasing in value.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: “Anxious of news of him. Asks for news of her young nephew, M. de Fontevieux, who sailed on the “Duchesse de Grammont.” (in French)

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: “Delivered a letter to Franklin from one of his correspondents at Amsterdam and left his address that the answer may be returned to his care.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: “Begging him to name the day and hour when he may obtain at the same time his memoir and Franklin’s opinion of it.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: “Writes in behalf of his brother-sufferers in Forton prison who are in want of the necessaries, whose relief would be great if they could get a small part of what is due them. Urges him particularly to assist Mr. Alexander Dick, a gentleman of considerable fortune in Virginia who is in a wretched state of health, and has not a farthing with which to purchase decent food.”

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Millin de la Brosse, Claude-Valentin. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: “Recalls that two years before, he obtained from Mr. Deane employment in the American army; unhappy result of that step; was harshly dealt with. Desires now to go to America, as a simple citizen; wishes a small piece of land in Pennsylvania or Maryland, suitable to his rank of lieutenant-colonel, a free passage over for himself and servant and some letters of recommendation.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: “His delay cause by finding that none of the prizes belonging to the Ranger had been sold and that the unfortunate crew had not received a single sou for all the time they had been in France; allowed then a respite of a day or two to sell their prizes and obtain their money; interference at this point of Captain Jones who threatened he would be the ruin of all those who meddled with the business; indignant at this conduct.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging him to find the plan of Gibraltar which was submitted to Dr. Franklin by M. [Barbeu] Dubourg, and to give it to his servant; desires news of Mr. [Jonathan] Williams [Jr.]’s health. (In French.)
